awd_titl_txt: The Pierre Auger Observatory Operating Funds Request
awd_abstract_narration:
Cosmic rays are highly energetic sub-atomic particles from space that travel at velocities near the speed of light.  The origin and acceleration mechanism for ultra-high energy cosmic rays, which likely come from extreme astrophysical phenomena outside our galaxy, are currently unknown.  The Pierre Auger Observatory is the largest cosmic ray detector ever operated, with an instrumented area of more than 3000 square kilometers.  Built in Malargue, Argentina by an international collaboration, the Pierre Auger Observatory was designed to study the origin and interactions of the highest energy particles in the Universe.  The Observatory has been operating since 2008.  This award provides partial funding for continued operations.  The Observatory will continue to be an important venue for the training of students and postdocs and will promote public outreach initiatives through its Visitor Center.  The public release of online data for school projects around the world will be expanded by implementing new tools for easy visualization and analysis. 

The Pierre Auger Observatory measures the energy spectrum, composition, and arrival direction of ultra-high energy cosmic rays.  More than 100,000 events have been detected with energies above 3x10^18 eV.  Over the course of this award, additional measurements, upgraded detectors, larger statistics, and improved data analysis methods will further advance our understanding of cosmic ray physics.

por.por_cntn:
The origin of Ultra-High Energy Cosmic Rays (UHECRs, energies up to and above 1020 eV) is a long-standing mystery in Particle Astrophysics, prompting some fundamental questions:

-        Where do they come from?

-        What kind of particles are they?

-        How can they be accelerated to such high energies, 10 billion times higher than those reached at the CERN Large Hadron Collider?

Answering these questions may radically change our understanding of the most extreme astrophysical objects in the universe, of the magnetic fields which permeate it, or of particle physics.

The tiny flux of these monster particles – less than one per km2 per century at the highest energy – motivated a large international collaboration of 18 countries to build in Argentina the world-largest cosmic ray detector, the Pierre Auger Observatory. Over its 3000 km2, particle showers produced by UHECRs are detected at ground by a sparse array of surface detectors (SD), and in the atmosphere by fluorescence detector (FD) telescopes sensitive to fluorescence light from nitrogen excited by the shower particles. Over the last decade the Observatory has detected hundreds of thousands of UHECRs, and advanced significantly our quest for their origin. A major outcome of this project is the precise measurement of the UHECRs flux as a function of energy, which shows a steep suppression at the highest energies, and several other features, still to be explained. Another major result is that the flux of UHECRs is not isotropic, namely they preferentially originate from some regions in the sky. These observations constitute an important step forward in our understanding of these exceptional particles, and motivate further investigations with an upgraded Auger Observatory currently in advanced stage of deployment.

Education and public outreach has been an integral part of the Pierre Auger Observatory. The project has enabled immersive research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students in a highly international setting, contributing to training in science and technology. These research experiences included collaboration with programs focused on under-represented to enhance diversity at the graduate and undergraduate levels. A large data set collected by the Observatory is available for educational and outreach with tools for easy visualization and analysis of extensive air showers. These tools are employed in activities for K-12 students, featuring analysis of Auger data as well as data from cosmic ray detectors developed for this purpose in many Auger institutions. UHECR science has been used to engage the local community, including specific programs for older adults. Partnerships with the Auger Visitors Center and the Malargue Planetarium in Argentina and similar institutions in the US have brought UHECR science to a broad and diverse audience.
